Section1.text: Throughout the 17th and 18th centuries, European and American slave merchants purchased enslaved Africans who were kidnapped and transported to the Americas and forced into slavery in the American colonies; exploited to work in a foreign land, fearful and lost in a new world to produce tobacco, wheat, indigo, rice, sugar and cotton crops.

Section2.text: These enslaved men and women worked in the northern cities of Boston and New York. They worked in the southern cities of Charleston, Richmond, and Baltimore.

Section3.text: By the mid 19th century, the America’s westward expansion and the abolition movement provoked a great debate over slavery that would tear the nation apart in the most deadly war in American history, The Civil War.

Section4.text: Though the Union victory freed the nation’s four million enslaved people, the legacy of slavery continues to influence American history.

Section5.text: From the Reconstruction era to the civil rights movement that emerged a century after emancipation, to Black Lives Matter and beyond.

Section6.text: The many paths taken, have twists and turns that lead to the unknown path of freedom for each individual from generation to generation.
